I've just confirmed that this bug is still present in WP 1.5 Gamma 2005-02-13. After editing a post, I had to use the WP-Admin interface to manage the post, and manually publish it again. MarsEdit 1.0 with WP 1.5 Gamma 2005-02-13.

I posted about it on my weblog at ​http://www.darcynorman.net/2005/02/06/trying-out-marsedit-again and Brent Simmons, the developer of MarsEdit, confirmed that he's seen the bug as well (and I've also filed it as a bug in MarsEdit just in case)

item.title: Ticket #865 (Wrong arguments for user_can_edit_user() in wp-admin/edit.php) updated
item.dc:creator: Agent Orange
item.description: Sorry, forgot to mention: The Version I recognized this problem in was the wordpress-2005-02-13 nightly build.

item.title: Ticket #865 (Wrong arguments for user_can_edit_user() in wp-admin/edit.php) updated
item.dc:creator: Agent Orange
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #865 (Wrong arguments for user_can_edit_user() in wp-admin/edit.php) created
item.dc:creator: Agent Orange
item.description:
When the list of posts is displayed, there are lines like this:

case 'control_delete':

?> <td><?php if ( user_can_edit_user($user_level,$authordata->user_level) ) { echo "<a href='post.php?action=delete&post=$id' class='delete' onclick=\"return confirm('" . sprintf(("You are about to delete this post \'%s\'
n \'OK\' to delete, \'Cancel\' to stop."), wp_specialchars(get_the_title(, ), 1) ) . "')\">" . ('Delete') . "</a>"; } ?></td> <?php break;

The arguments for user_can_edit_user() are completely wrong here. The correct line would look like:

case 'control_edit':

?> <td><?php if ( user_can_edit_user($user_ID,$authordata->ID) ) { echo "<a href='post.php?action=edit&post=$id' class='edit'>" . ('Edit') . "</a>"; } ?></td> <?php break;

So, you have to submit the user id's to the function user_can_edit_user, not the levels.

item.title: Ticket #864 (Only 1 single entry showing in feeds) updated
item.dc:creator: Morgaine
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #864 (Only 1 single entry showing in feeds) created
item.dc:creator: Morgaine
item.description:
When using 1.5-gamma 2005-02-12, with 'Blog pages, Show at most' set to 1 post in the admin interface, Options - Reading, and 'Syndication feeds, Show the most recent 10 posts, For each article, show Full text', there is only 1 post in the feed as well. Changing 'Blog pages, Show at most' to e.g. 10, makes the feeds behave as expected. When changing it back to 1, the feeds contain only 1 entry, even though it's set to contain 10 posts.

In 1.5-beta-1 2005-01-28 the problem didn't occur.

item.description:

item.title: Ticket #863 (Allow theme location to be changed through filters.) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Sample plugin attached.

item.title: Ticket #863 (Allow theme location to be changed through filters.) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
Here's the list of filters:

theme_root - The base theme directory. Default: ABSPATH/wp-content/themes

theme_root_uri - The base theme uri. Default: siteurl/wp-content/themes

stylesheet_directory - The directory containing the active stylesheet. Default: theme_root/stylesheet-theme-name

stylesheet_directory_uri - The uri of the directory containing the active stylesheet. Default: theme_root_uri/stylesheet-theme-name

stylesheet_uri - The uri of the active stylesheet. Default: stylesheet_directory_uri/style.css

template_directory - The directory containing the active template. Default: theme_root/template-theme-name

template_directory_uri - The uri of the directory containing the active template. Default: theme_root_uri/template-theme-name

To relocate from wp-contet/themes/ to /themes/, hook into the theme_root and theme_root_uri filters. Changes made to those will be picked up by the stylesheets and templates.

item.title: Ticket #863 (Allow theme location to be changed through filters.) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #863 (Allow theme location to be changed through filters.) created
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Add filters so that the theme root, template directory, stylesheet directory, and associated URIs can be changed via plugins.

item.title: Ticket #862 (wp-rss2.php doesn't include language element) updated
item.dc:creator: dnorman
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #862 (wp-rss2.php doesn't include language element) created
item.dc:creator: dnorman
item.description:
The wp-rss2.php file does not include the <language>en</language> element for the channel. This is causing audio.weblogs.com to barf on it.

It's simple to add in... In line 29, just add:

<language>en</language>

Bonus points for using the actual weblog's configured language, instead of "en".

item.title: Ticket #859 (Custom comment template broken) updated
item.dc:creator: gudlyf
item.description:
I found the problem. In some of the provided templates with WP 1.5, this line in index.php:

<?php comments_template( is_single() ); Get wp-comments.php template ?>

Needs to be:

<?php comments_template(); Get wp-comments.php template ?>

item.title: Ticket #859 (Custom comment template broken) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description:
Status changed

In your template (index.php), are you sending a non-filename argument to comments_template()?

item.title: Ticket #858 (Always load the comments.php from the default theme) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description: The argument to comments_template() needs to either be empty (in which case the function will first try to obtain the theme-specific comments template, and failing that, will use the default theme's comments template), or the argument needs to specify the name of the comments template (that file would need to exist in current theme's directory).

item.title: Ticket #858 (Always load the comments.php from the default theme) updated
item.dc:creator: Lucky
item.description:
I have looked in the index.php and found that at line 28: <?php comments_template( is_single() ); Get wp-comments.php template ?>

I think thats the call? So I have a parameter, or not? But it include only the comments.php from default theme.

Another think, why is the $file declaration in the function parameter not in the function itself?

edited on: 02-12-05 14:06

item.title: Ticket #860 (classic theme's index.php calls comments_template() w/ incorrect arg) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #860 (classic theme's index.php calls comments_template() w/ incorrect arg) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #860 (classic theme's index.php calls comments_template() w/ incorrect arg) created
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description: comments_template() (in wp-includes/comments-functions.php) was recently changed to accept a filename as its arg. The classic theme's index.php [wp-content/themes/classic/index.php] calls comments_template() with an arg of is_single(), which isn't a filename and will therefore cause the default comments template (in wp-content/themes/default/) to be used.

item.title: Ticket #859 (Custom comment template broken) updated
item.dc:creator: gudlyf
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #859 (Custom comment template broken) created
item.dc:creator: gudlyf
item.description: It looks like the patch related to #0000632 broke custom comment templates. The path doesn't look right.

item.title: Ticket #858 (Always load the comments.php from the default theme) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description:
Status changed

The function comments_template() sets the default for $file to be "/comments.php". All WP calls to comments_template() do so without an argument (except for in the classic theme's index.php, which I'll file a bug for), so the default would be used (which when specified looks into the current theme's directory).

So I'm left to wonder... in your template, what does the call to comments_template() look like? If you're sending an argument, is it something other than a comments template filename?

item.title: Ticket #821 (Better DB connection failure page for public-facing site) updated
item.dc:creator: matt
item.description: Priority changed

item.title: Ticket #857 (Override HTTP 'Content-Type:' header) updated
item.dc:creator: morganiq
item.description: Summary changed

item.title: Ticket #857 (Override HTTP 'Content-Type:' header) updated
item.dc:creator: morganiq
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #857 (Override HTTP 'Content-Type:' header) created
item.dc:creator: morganiq
item.description:
WordPress allows users to set the character set they want to use, and this value goes in the <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" /> tag. However, unless the user has set PHP and/or Apache to deliver the HTTP Content-Type header with the same value, the two could be in conflict.

Browsers give precedence to the HTTP header over its <meta> tag equivalent, meaning that regardless of the charset a user enters on Options > Reading, their browser will continue to use whichever charset the HTTP header specifies for reading and writing.

Rather than leaving it up to users to make sure the two are in sync, WP should use header() to set the 'Content-Type' header in addition to its <meta> equivalent.

item.title: Ticket #108 (I get an XML Parsing Error whenever i got to my journals rss feeds) closed
item.dc:creator: matt
item.description:
50:

Without fail this is ALWAYS due to a plugin extra whitespace or whitespace in a user-edited file like wp-config.php.
